title: Paul's Shipwreck
shortSummary: Acts 27 recounts the perilous sea voyage of the Apostle Paul as he is transported to Rome as a prisoner. Despite warnings and severe storms, God’s providence ensures the safety of all aboard, demonstrating His sovereign protection over His servants. This chapter highlights faith, divine reassurance, and the fulfillment of God’s promises.
timeline: c. AD 60 - Paul's voyage to Rome

keyCharacters.name: Paul
keyCharacters.description: The apostle and prisoner whose faith and leadership provide hope and guidance during the storm and shipwreck.

keyCharacters.name: Julius
keyCharacters.description: A Roman centurion responsible for Paul and the prisoners, showing kindness and authority throughout the voyage.

keyCharacters.name: Ship's Master
keyCharacters.description: The experienced sailor in charge of navigating the ship, whose decisions impact the journey’s progress.

keyCharacters.name: Soldiers
keyCharacters.description: Roman guards tasked with overseeing the prisoners, involved in decisions during the crisis.

definitions.definition: A Roman army officer in charge of approximately one hundred soldiers, responsible for discipline and order.
A violent northeast wind or tempestuous storm mentioned in Acts 27:14, causing great danger to the ship.
Unstable, shifting sand or mud that can trap and swallow objects or people, posing a hazard to ships near shore.
A religious period of fasting and prayer, likely the Day of Atonement, marking a solemn time for Jewish believers.

outline.heading: Paul’s Journey Begins and Initial Sailing
outline.description: Paul is handed over to Julius and begins his voyage to Italy, sailing along the coast with other prisoners. Despite Paul's warnings about the dangers of continuing the voyage, the centurion trusts the ship’s crew and decides to sail on.

outline.heading: The Storm and Ship’s Struggles
outline.description: A violent storm called Euroclydon arises, causing the ship to be caught and driven helplessly. The crew takes measures to lighten the ship and prevent disaster, but the situation grows increasingly desperate.

outline.heading: Paul’s Encouragement and Divine Assurance
outline.description: Paul encourages the crew and passengers, sharing the angelic message that all will survive and that he must appear before Caesar. This divine reassurance strengthens their hope amid the crisis.

outline.heading: Preparation for Shipwreck and Survival
outline.description: As the ship nears land, the crew takes precautions to avoid rocks and anchors the ship. Paul instructs the soldiers to keep the prisoners aboard for their safety. The ship runs aground, but through God’s protection, everyone reaches shore safely.

application: Trust God’s guidance even when circumstances seem dire, as Paul did during the storm.
Encourage and lead others with faith and hope in times of crisis, reflecting Christ’s peace.
Obey godly warnings and counsel to avoid unnecessary harm, but also rely on God’s sovereignty when trials come.
Remember that God’s promises are sure, and He is able to protect and deliver His people in all situations.

keyVerses.text: For there stood by me this night the angel of God, whose I am, and whom I serve, Saying, Fear not, Paul; thou must be brought before Caesar: and, lo, God hath given thee all them that sail with thee.
keyVerses.significance: This verse reveals God’s direct intervention and reassurance to Paul, affirming His sovereign care over the journey and all aboard.

keyVerses.text: Paul said to the centurion and to the soldiers, Except these abide in the ship, ye cannot be saved.
keyVerses.significance: Paul’s leadership and faith guide the decisions that ultimately preserve the lives of everyone on the ship.

keyVerses.text: And the rest, some on boards, and some on broken pieces of the ship. And so it came to pass, that they escaped all safe to land.
keyVerses.significance: This verse highlights God’s miraculous deliverance of all aboard despite the shipwreck, underscoring His power to save.
